Name: Nerol
Description: Nerol is the (2Z)-stereoisomer of 3,7-dimethylocta-2,6-dien-1-ol. It has been isolated from the essential oils from plants like lemon grass. It has a role as a volatile oil component, a plant metabolite and a fragrance.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Sell CS; Terpenoids. Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology. (1999-2015). New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons. Online Posting Date: Sep 15, 2006. (2) Fahlbusch KG et al; Flavors and Fragrances. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry. 7th ed. (1999-2015). New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons. Online Posting Date: Jan 15, 2003. (3) Rodgman A, Perfetti TA; The Chemical Components of Tobacco and Tobacco Smoke, 2nd ed. Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press, Taylor & Francis Group, p. 1274 (2013) (4) Stojanovic S et al; Nat Prod Commum 9(11): 1609-12 (2014) (5) Verma RS et al; Nat Prod Res 25(17): 1577-84 (2011) (6) Tatsuka K et al; J Agric Food Chem 38: 2176-80 (1990)
plant_concentrations.Value: Nerol and geraniol are widespread in nature and occur in plants such as Monarda fistulosa, palmarosa (Cymbopogon martini), citronella (Cymbopogon nardus, C. winterianus), lemongrass (Cymbopogon citratus), and geranium(1); nerol concentration is highest in rose, palmarosa, citronella, and davana(1). Nerol occurs in small quantities in many essential oils(2). Nerol has been detected in tobacco(3). Nerol was detected in the essential oil of three Thymus species (Thymus glabrescens, T. praecox and T. pulegoides)(4). The essential oil of rose water (Rosa damascena Mill.) from northern India contained nerol at concentrations of 4.0-9.6%(5). Nerol was identified in the volatile components of kiwi fruit flowers(6).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) USDA; Dr. Duke's Phytochemical and Ethnobotanical Databases. Plants with a chosen chemical. Nerol. Washington, DC: US Dept Agric, Agric Res Service. Available from, as of July 22, 2015: https://www.ars-grin.gov/duke/
